Award.AwardTitle: Personalized Genetics and Genealogy exercises to enhance introductory biology courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Spelman College seeks to test a novel approach to increase student engagement in STEM fields at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), through development of an introductory biology course intervention centered on a genetics and genealogy (G&G) approach. This personally relevant curriculum is considered key in attracting and retaining minority students. The approach is expected to be more successful than current approaches at: 1) promoting content knowledge learning; 2) generating enthusiasm for science; and 3) increasing scientific literacy with respect to evolutionary theory. This project will have the long-term impact of reducing attrition of underrepresented students from life sciences.

The G&G approach is aimed at stimulating interest in the study of science and the pursuit of a STEM career by priming students with the discovery of unique facts about themselves, their history, and their relatedness to other humans in the world. This project will contribute to the field of STEM education by providing: 1) a new pedagogical model for combining personalization with a discovery-based approach in an interdisciplinary context; 2) a strategy for addressing the truly challenging issue of the low acceptance of evolution among students in a unique way; 3) a "STEAM" model to meaningfully incorporate visual art and narrative into Biology education; and 4) a model for faculty development and networking through the adoption of a popular social networking site for the same.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study personalized the curriculum by means of using student genetic data as a strategy for student engagement, improved science literacy, and improved success rates in Biology courses.  We tested this novel approach at three top-ranked Historically Black institutions (Spelman, Morehouse, NC A&T) in over more than half a dozen courses in Biology through an intervention centered on a genetics and genealogy (G&G) of students using data from Direct-to-consumer DNA kit (23andme).

 

BROADER IMPACTS: In the course of four years, 311 students in introductory biology classes and 85 students in advanced Biology electives have experienced the G&G approach at Spelman. An additional 110 students at Morehouse College and 54 at NC A&T have experienced the introductory biology G&G curriculum. Thus, 100s of African American students have benefitted from exposure to G&G intervention in their college courses. Exposure to genomic sciences in this ?age of genome? will be particularly beneficial to students in making them aware of some cutting edge computational and molecular tools of value in the STEM workforce. The interdisciplinary nature of the exploration ensures that students will learn to integrate knowledge from various disciplines. Assigning students a STEAM project challenging them to create an artistic expression or narrative of some aspect of their G&G data they wish to explore in depth, gives them ownership to develop deep learning, whereas providing opportunities to learn the use to technology tools in the innovation and recording lab helps them develop technical skills. Over two dozen faculty and future faculty at these and surrounding institutions have received training via faculty development workshops. The products resulting from curriculum development (G&G modules) as well as publications based on assessment will be invaluable to the education community.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The advances in genomic science and education technology provide the unique opportunity to envision a G & G curriculum which is personalized to each student by using their genetic information to study biology. Combined with an investigative, interdisciplinary, and integrative approach-it is truly rigorous as well as relevant. Though the project is proposed for minority students at HBCs? the G&G modules are effective for all students. Our results indicate that this strategy is indeed effective at engaged student learning as well as improving student success in the courses as measured by pass rates. Thus we anticipate that this project will contribute to the field of STEM education by providing a new potentially transformative pedagogical model for combining personalization with other discovery based approaches in an interdisciplinary context and a STEAM model for meaningfully incorporating visual art and narrative into Biology education.
